Cultural Context

Creating culturally safe spaces (wÄhi haumaru) is essential for MÄori student success. This resource draws on key concepts:

  • Manaakitanga - Showing respect, hospitality and care for others
  • Whanaungatanga - Building and maintaining relationships
  • Wairuatanga - Spiritual wellbeing and connection
  • Kotahitanga - Unity and working together

Tikanga Considerations: When discussing MÄori topics, ensure you:

  • Pronounce MÄori words correctly (practice with students)
  • Use appropriate protocols (tikanga) when discussing sensitive topics
  • Provide opportunities for whÄnau (family) involvement where appropriate
  • Recognize diverse MÄori perspectives and experiences

Cultural Safety Checklists

Use these checklists to evaluate and improve cultural safety in your classroom discussions:

Before Discussion Checklist

I have considered the cultural backgrounds of all students
I have prepared correct pronunciation of MÄori terms
I have identified potential sensitive areas in the topic
I have established discussion protocols with students
Alternative participation methods are available

During Discussion Checklist

I'm monitoring student comfort levels
All voices are being heard equally
Cultural perspectives are valued equally
MÄori worldviews are given appropriate space
The discussion remains respectful

After Discussion Checklist

I've provided time for reflection
Students have debriefing options
I've noted areas for improvement
Follow-up support is available
Feedback has been gathered

Interactive: Cultural Safety Scenario

Read this scenario and discuss in small groups how you would respond:

"During a discussion about land rights, a PÄkehÄ student says 'MÄori get too many special privileges.' Several MÄori students look uncomfortable. One rolls their eyes and stops participating."

Assessment Rubric

Criteria Emerging (1-2) Developing (3-4) Proficient (5-6) Advanced (7-8)
Cultural Awareness Limited recognition of cultural differences Some awareness but inconsistent application Consistent awareness and appropriate responses Deep understanding and proactive cultural safety
Inclusivity Few voices heard, dominant perspectives prevail Some attempt to include diverse views Most students contribute meaningfully All students actively engaged and valued
Respectful Dialogue Frequent cultural insensitivities Basic respect shown but some lapses Consistent respectful interactions Models and promotes exemplary cultural respect
Reflection Little reflection on cultural impacts Some reflection but superficial Thoughtful analysis of cultural dynamics Deep reflection and application to future practice

Extension Activities

1. Cultural Safety Audit

Work in groups to assess another aspect of school life (e.g., sports, library, playground) using cultural safety principles. Present findings and recommendations.

2. WhakataukÄ« (Proverb) Analysis

Research MÄori proverbs about respect and community. Choose one that relates to cultural safety and create a poster explaining its relevance to classroom discussions.

3. Cross-Cultural Comparison

Investigate how another culture (e.g., Pasifika, Asian) approaches respectful discussion. Compare and contrast with MÄori approaches.

Teacher Implementation Notes

Preparation

  • Familiarize yourself with correct MÄori pronunciation using MÄori Dictionary
  • Consult with MÄori colleagues or community members about sensitive topics
  • Prepare visual aids that reflect MÄori culture and perspectives

During Implementation

  • Begin with a karakia (prayer/invocation) if appropriate for your school context
  • Use think-pair-share strategies to allow processing time
  • Have a "pass" option for students who don't wish to speak
  • Watch for non-verbal cues of discomfort

Follow-up

  • Provide anonymous feedback options
  • Reflect on what worked well and areas for improvement
  • Share successes with colleagues to promote school-wide cultural safety

Resources & References

  • Ministry of Education - Schooling for MÄori Students
  • Te Marautanga o Aotearoa
  • Te Aka MÄori Dictionary
  • Te Kaharoa Journal (for academic perspectives)
  • Bishop, R. (2011). Freeing Ourselves. Brill.
  • Macfarlane, A. (2004). Kia Hiwa Ra! Listen to Culture. NZCER Press.
